text:
(1)
25 South Street, west side, at Coenties Slip, showing the Seamen's Institute.
August 10, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at an earlier date, showing a view farther north. The Seamen's Institute also bears Nos. 26-20 Coenties Slip and has a 13-story addition (seen in view No. 1) which replaced the 4-story house, shown at the extreme left in view No. 2.
1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Another view of the Seamen's Institute at a later date than view No. 2, as seen from a different angle, showing also (left to right) piers No. 4 to 8 East River. At the extreme right (background) can faintly be seen part of Fort Jay, Governor's Island.
August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

*ASSUMING STREET TO BE NORTH AND SOUTH*

title: Manhattan: South Street - Coenties Slip

text:
(1) Coenties Slip, north side, east from and including Front, to and including South Streets. Shown is the Seamen's Institute (25 South Street). October 9, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a complete view of Jeanette Park. Also seen is South Street, with Piers Nos. 6, 7 and 8, projecting onto the East River. October 9, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, and showing the U.S. Army dirigible "Los Angeles". November 2, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST
title: Manhattan: Coenties Slip - Front Street

text:
(1) Coenties Slip, north side, east from and including Front, to and including South Streets. Shown is the Seamen's Institute (25 South Street). October 9, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a complete view of Jeanette Park. Also seen is South Street, with Piers Nos. 6, 7 and 8, projecting onto the East River. October 9, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, and showing the U.S. Army dirigible "Los Angeles". November 2, 1931. P. L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST
title: Manhattan: Coenties Slip - Front Street

text:

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST
title: Manhattan: Coenties Slip - Front Street

text:
(1) A general view, west from the Seaman's Institute, 25 South Street, at the N.W. corner of Coenties Slip, showing the tower of No. 60 Wall Street, (between Pearl and William Streets), in the centre.

August 4, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

August 4, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - [Manhattan - South Street - Seaman's Institute (West).]

text:
(1) A general view, west from the Seaman's Institute, 25 South Street, at the N.W. corner of Coenties Slip, showing the tower of No. 60 Wall Street, (between Pearl and William Streets), in the centre.

August 4, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

August 4, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - [Manhattan - South Street - Seaman's Institute (West).]

text:
25 South Street (Seaman's Church Institute), at the N. W. corner of Coenties Slip, (panoramic view northward).

A set of three views forming a panorama of Wall Street financial structures. From left to right these are, the International Telephone Co., the Continental Bank and Trust Co., the Irving Trust Co., the Equitable Trust Co., the City Bank Farmers Trust Co., the Bank of New York, the Wall and Hanover, and the Sixty Wall Tower Buildings. The first of these are on Broad Street (exclusive of the Irving Trust Co., Building), the balance on Wall Street. Erected between 1929-1931 they form the nucleus and theme of this district.
In the foreground are low structures, fronting on Front, Water and Pearl Streets. The latter thoroughfare is the dividing line between the two different types of buildings shown.

August 4, 1934
Views 1, 2, 3

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - [Manhattan - South Street - Seaman's Church Institute (North) - Panoramic view of Wall Street financial structures.]

text:

The first of these are on Broad Street (exclusive of the Irving Trust Co., Building), the balance on Wall Street. Erected between 1929-1931 they form the nucleus and theme of this district.
In the foreground are low structures, fronting on Front, Water and Pearl Streets. The latter thoroughfare is the dividing line between the two different types of buildings shown.

August 4, 1934
Views 1, 2, 3

P. L. Sperr
